A solutions architect needs to design a new microservice for a company’s application. Clients must be able to call an HTTPS endpoint to reach the microservice. The microservice also must use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to authenticate calls. The solutions architect will write the logic for this microservice by using a single AWS Lambda function that is written in Go 1.x.

Which solution will deploy the function in the MOST operationally efficient way?

A. Create an Amazon API Gateway REST API. Configure the method to use the Lambda function. Enable IAM authentication on the API.
B. Create a Lambda function URL for the function. Specify AWS\_IAM as the authentication type.
C. Create an Amazon CloudFront distribution. Deploy the function to Lambda@Edge. Integrate IAM authentication logic into the Lambda@Edge function.
D. Create an Amazon CloudFront distribution. Deploy the function to CloudFront Functions. Specify AWS\_IAM as the authentication type.

The solution that will deploy the function in the most operationally efficient way for a new microservice that clients can call through an HTTPS endpoint and must use IAM authentication is:

A. Create an Amazon API Gateway REST API. Configure the method to use the Lambda function. Enable IAM authentication on the API.

Explanation:

Option A is the best solution because it is a fully managed service that is specifically designed for building and deploying APIs that can be used by clients. It also supports integrating with Lambda functions, which can be written in Go 1.x. With Amazon API Gateway, it is possible to configure the REST API method to use the Lambda function as the backend, and enable IAM authentication on the API, which ensures that only authorized clients can call the API. This option is also scalable, as it can handle high volumes of traffic without the need for managing and scaling infrastructure.

Option B, creating a Lambda function URL for the function and specifying AWS\_IAM as the authentication type, is not the best option because it does not provide a scalable or secure way to authenticate and authorize clients. This option requires clients to include an IAM user's access key and secret access key in the request, which is not recommended for security reasons.

Option C, creating an Amazon CloudFront distribution and deploying the function to Lambda@Edge, is not the best option because it is more complex and expensive than using Amazon API Gateway. Additionally, integrating IAM authentication logic into the Lambda@Edge function can introduce additional complexity and security risks.

Option D, creating an Amazon CloudFront distribution and deploying the function to CloudFront Functions, is not the best option because CloudFront Functions is currently in preview and does not support IAM authentication. Additionally, it is not designed for deploying and managing APIs, and may not be suitable for this use case.

An online learning company is migrating to the AWS Cloud. The company maintains its student records in a PostgreSQL database. The company needs a solution in which its data is available and online across multiple AWS Regions at all times.

Which solution will meet these requirements with the LEAST amount of operational overhead?

A. Migrate the PostgreSQL database to a PostgreSQL cluster on Amazon EC2 instances.
B. Migrate the PostgreSQL database to an Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL DB instance with the Multi-AZ feature turned on.
C. Migrate the PostgreSQL database to an Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL DB instance. Create a read replica in another Region.
D. Migrate the PostgreSQL database to an Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL DB instance. Set up DB snapshots to be copied to another Region.

The solution that will meet the requirements of making the student records in a PostgreSQL database available and online across multiple AWS Regions at all times with the least amount of operational overhead for an online learning company migrating to AWS is:

C. Migrate the PostgreSQL database to an Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL DB instance. Create a read replica in another Region.

Explanation:

Option C is the best solution because it is designed to replicate data asynchronously to another Region, providing disaster recovery and availability benefits. Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL offers the capability to create a read replica in another AWS Region, which can be used for disaster recovery and to serve read traffic from the Region where the replica is created. The read replica can also be promoted to become the new master in the event of a failure in the primary Region. This option has the least amount of operational overhead because Amazon RDS takes care of the replication and failover processes, and it requires minimal setup and management.

Option A, migrating the PostgreSQL database to a PostgreSQL cluster on Amazon EC2 instances, is not the best option because it requires more operational overhead than Amazon RDS, including managing the instances, the data replication, and backups.

Option B, migrating the PostgreSQL database to an Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL DB instance with the Multi-AZ feature turned on, is not the best option because it only provides disaster recovery in the same AWS Region, and it may not be sufficient for the company's needs of having data available and online across multiple AWS Regions.

Option D, migrating the PostgreSQL database to an Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL DB instance and setting up DB snapshots to be copied to another Region, is not the best option because it is not designed for replication and it requires more operational overhead than using read replicas.

A company is launching an application on AWS. The application uses an Application Load Balancer (ALB) to direct traffic to at least two Amazon EC2 instances in a single target group. The instances are in an Auto Scaling group for each environment. The company requires a development environment and a production environment. The production environment will have periods of high traffic.

Which solution will configure the development environment MOST cost-effectively?

A. Reconfigure the target group in the development environment to have only one EC2 instance as a target.
B. Change the ALB balancing algorithm to least outstanding requests.
C. Reduce the size of the EC2 instances in both environments.
D. Reduce the maximum number of EC2 instances in the development environment’s Auto Scaling group.

The MOST cost-effective solution to configure the development environment would be to reconfigure the target group to have only one EC2 instance as a target. This would reduce the number of instances running in the development environment, which would reduce costs associated with running those instances. Additionally, having only one instance as a target in the development environment would also make it easier to test changes to the application before deploying to the production environment, as there would be less variability in the environment.

Option D could also be a cost-effective solution for the development environment, as it would limit the number of instances that can be launched and would reduce the overall cost of running the environment. However, it could also limit the ability to test and develop the application under certain conditions, especially if the application needs to be tested under heavy load or with multiple instances. Therefore, it may not be the best solution if the company needs to have a comprehensive testing and development environment.

A company runs a web application on Amazon EC2 instances in multiple Availability Zones. The EC2 instances are in private subnets. A solutions architect implements an internet-facing Application Load Balancer (ALB) and specifies the EC2 instances as the target group. However, the internet traffic is not reaching the EC2 instances.

How should the solutions architect reconfigure the architecture to resolve this issue?

A. Replace the ALB with a Network Load Balancer. Configure a NAT gateway in a public subnet to allow internet traffic.
B. Move the EC2 instances to public subnets. Add a rule to the EC2 instances’ security groups to allow outbound traffic to 0.0.0.0/0.
C. Update the route tables for the EC2 instances’ subnets to send 0.0.0.0/0 traffic through the internet gateway route. Add a rule to the EC2 instances’ security groups to allow outbound traffic to 0.0.0.0/0.
D. Create public subnets in each Availability Zone. Associate the public subnets with the ALB. Update the route tables for the public subnets with a route to the private subnets.

Option C is the correct answer.

The issue is that the EC2 instances are in private subnets and there is no route for internet traffic to reach them. The solution is to update the route tables for the private subnets to send internet traffic through the NAT gateway. This will allow internet traffic to reach the EC2 instances while still keeping them in private subnets for security reasons.

Option A is incorrect because it suggests replacing the ALB with a Network Load Balancer, which does not address the issue of private subnets and internet traffic.

Option B is incorrect because it suggests moving the EC2 instances to public subnets, which may not be desirable for security reasons.

Option D is incorrect because it suggests creating public subnets for the ALB, which again may not be desirable for security reasons. Additionally, there is no need to update the route tables for the public subnets with a route to the private subnets since the private subnets will already have a route to the public subnets via the NAT gateway.
